bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 30, 1900

div1.p: Reed describes his voyage to Havana, during which he gives medical care to a child. Emilie Lawrence Reed would not accompany Reed to Cuba, and did not want him to go.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 30, 1900
div1.opener:
100 miles South
of Hatteras, n. c.
Sunday morning, Sept. 30
Installment No. 1- My darling wifie;
div1.p:
You probably think
that by this time that bad man
who would go to Cuba when
he needn't have gone, is good
and sick, and my dear Room-
fixer is possibly happy in the
thought! But don't congratulate
yourself too quickly, lovie, dear,
for you might be mistaken-
Here I sit at 8.30 a.m., this
beautiful, balmy sabbath morn-
ing, with my feet propped
on the rail, while the good
boat, Crook, plunges and rolls
as the necessity of wind and
wave seems to require, and I,
poor sailor that I am, am not
feeling even a suspicion of
sea-sickness! Bromide of
sodium is doing its work,
this time beyond a doubt; and
you can depend upon it that
I am not missing a dose!
As we got out to sea from
New York there was a heavy
swell on, but our boat be-
haved beautifully and she has
continued to do so- Passing
Hatteras at 8 o'clock, last
evening, the sea was quieter
than I had ever seen it at
that treacherous part of the
coast. This morning the
sea is so beautiful -- not
many white caps, but some-
thing of a ground swell, which
makes our boat roll a wee
bit -- just enough to stir up
the gizzards of land-lubbers.
I see a few who are pale about
the gills, and I so sympathize
with them for I know, to my
horror, what sensations
they feel- There are about
a dozen army ladies with
their children returning to
Matanzas and Columbia Barracks-
A young contract Doctor, by
the name of Cooke, a graduate
of the University of Va. is my
state-room companion -- strange
to say he goes to Columbia
Barracks and will be my mess-
mate there- He is a Virginian
and a modest & refined fellow.
Major Godfrey and Cap't. Waterman
of the 7th Cav. and Cap't. Lewis of the
2nd Cav. are aboard- Their families
all accompany them to Camp Co-
lumbia. I wish that my Sweet
oomsey & baby-cocoon were
going along with old Mr Farmer.
Perhaps, you will change your
mind yet, & come down in Decr
if only for two weeks- You could
then have the pleasure of my com-
pany on your return trip-

off the Georgia Coast,
Monday Morning -- 10 a.m.
October 1st 1900-

Well, as my dear oomsey has
positively sworn, in her wrath,
that she will only write to that
bad man, every other week only,
I think I will have to supply the
letters from this end of the line!
If you don't want to be both-
ered with reading them, just
turn them over to dear little
cocoon & let her decipher them-
The day passed very quietly
yesterday- The sea was just a
little rough but not enough
to counteract the effect of my
good Sodium Bromide- Not
one sail or smokestack came
in sight during the whole day-
In other words, we had the whole
broad Atlantic all to ourselves.
The flying-fish doubtless thought
that we were lonesome, so
they came & skimmed over the
water alongside our good boat.
I spent the morning in reading
& after lunch, I slept three
solid hours! During the eve-
ning the beautiful little boy
baby of Mrs. Lt. Harrison,
on her way to join her hus-
band at Matanzas, had a
convulsions & I aided the ship's
doctor in administering to
its wants- She reminds me
very much of Mrs. Weaver
both in looks and pluck- The
little boy, who is as fine a
specimen as I ever saw, ex-
cept our own, is better, this
morning- Good weather still
attends us and the captain
says that the barometer in-
dicates clear weather- We
go first to Matanzas, about
50 miles from Havana, and
there unload a lot of hay &
oats for the 2nd Cav., and then to
Havana- We will not reach
the latter harbor until the
evening of the 4th or morn-
ing of the 5th of October-
I don't care as long as
I am not sea-sick- I will
get a chance to mail this
on Saturday at Havana- Now
that we are further south, the
air is much warmer at sea
than it was on the evening when
we pulled out of N.Y. Harbor-
I have already left off my
waistcoat and put on my white
cap, whose cover the dearest
room-fixer in the world, cleaned
so nicely for me- Mr Bad
man thanks Miss Room-fixer
very much for her kind attention
to his head-gear. We are having
very good meals 3 times a day-
I enjoyed, last evening, very much
a potatoe-salad with sliced
cucumbers- The sliced tomatoes,
are also, delicious- Boo! Boo!

20 miles South of
Miami, Fla,
Tuesday morning,
Oct. 2nd 10 a.m.

Don't
read this
lovie, if
it makes
your heart
ache!

We are having a little more life
to-day than we had yesterday-
We have been coasting along
the shore of Florida since mid-
night, last night, and at 8 a.m.
we were running along past
Miami, Fla- Now we see the
pretty Florida keys and to one
who hasn't seen land no for 3
days, the sight of the white
sand and the green foliage
is most welcome- We are
running along about 1 mile from
shore and the sea is almost
as smooth as glass. The little
white cottages throw back the
sun's rays so prettily, but not
half so effectively as our dear
little Keewaydin- I wonder
if Johnnie Moore is hard at
work, this morning, rolling
together the big stones to put
in the fence and to give room
for those Albemarle pippins
and early strawberry apples-
I would give a dollar just
to be present and look over
that valley for 15 minutes.
I also wonder whether the
dear, sweet lady who fixes
rooms so sweetly, has written
me one line since I left!
I guess not -- or if she has
done so, it has been only
from a sense of duty and
much against her will-
She doesn't have much use
for bad men who run off
to Cuba against her advice,
but she can tolerate a
man who makes a ter-
raced garden with plenty
of room for flower-beds!
What a queer, queer world
this is anyway! Isn't it so,
sweet Room-fixer? But
you must come down on
this good boat & see
Cuba for 2 or 3 weeks
before my return- Then you
will feel more sympathy
for poor old Mr Mantee!
I wish your artistic eye
& dear little Cocoon's could
catch the glint of green &
purple along the shore- You
would be delighted with
the effect- The Florida
keys surely never looked
prettier than they do, this
October morning. We will
be opposite key west, this
evening, & will enter Ma-
tanzas Harbor tomorrow
morning about the hour
when precious Cocoon is
on her way to school! Boo! Boo!

At anchor in
Matanzas Harbor,
Wednesday, 9 a.m.

When I awoke at 4.30 a.m., I went
out on deck in my pajamas and
found that our ship was at a
stand still, while the waves gentle
lapped her white sides- Through
the pale light of morning I could
catch the outline of the Cuban
shore and the light of the flash-
light that doubtless marked
the entrance to Matanzas
Harbor- I sat out in the
deliciously cool morning
air for a while, only clothed
in my pajamas- After a
while I turned in again,
and when I was next awakened,
the anchor chain was rattling
at a loud rate- I then knew
that we were in the Harbor
of Matanzas- Pretty soon a
number of officers came aboard
to greet their wives and babies-
I find that I have made a
life-long friend of Mrs. Harrison,
my attention to her little sick
boy has quite won her heart-
The ship's doctor, a fat, lub-
berly contract, was so indif-
ferent, that my heart was
touched & I did everything that
I could to assist her- The
little fellow, a beautiful boy,
was alright & smiling as
he left the ship in his father's
arms- Both the Lt. & his wife
were very profuse in their
thanks- Army people are the
most grateful in the world-
We now ride at anchor in
a very pretty Harbor- Op-
posite to us, is Hamilton
Barracks, where all of the
2nd Cav. is stationed -- a beau-
tiful location, amidst green
hills- I shouldn't object to
it as a station- Amongst the
officers who came aboard ashore
I met Capt. Folz, our Dr
Keefer's brother-in-law, with whom
I messed & campaigned in Mon-
tana in 1891- He seemed very
glad to meet me- I certainly
was glad to see him, as he
was so kind & courteous
to me on that journey in Montana.
The City of Matanzas lies beau-
tifully on sloping hill-sides-
Higher hills serve as a back
-ground- It is said to be very
clean & has no Yellow Fever-
I find that I could take a
train at 3.15 P.M. & reach Havan-
a at 6 o'clock, to-day, -- I would
like to go, as it only costs, #2.00
& I could save 24 hours; but
as it would put me in the city
after dark, when mosquitoes
fly around & bite, and as
I have promised dear Mrs.
Room-fixer that I will take
no chances, I won't take the trip-
Am I not a good mantee! Boo! Boo!

off the coast of Cuba,
Near Matanzas, Thursday morning
October 4th 10 o'clock-

We rested at anchor in the Harbor of
Matanzas all day, yesterday, while cargo was
being discharged -- we left 2700 bales
of hay and 2700 bags of oats for the
2nd Cav along -- besides 700 other pieces of cargo-
Thunder-showers in the early afternoon
tempered the air & made it perfectly
delicious- The night, with an almost
cloudless sky & a bright moon, was
beautiful beyond description- I thought
of dear Miss Room-fixer & precious
little Cocoon & wished so much that they
could see what Papa was seeing-
At 8.30 a.m. we weighed anchor and sailed
out of the beautiful Harbor, while the
whole 2nd Cavalry was drilling on the
shore at full view- Now we are
skimming over the blue waters at a dis-
tance of half a miles from the Cuban
shore which can only be described as
fascinatingly beautiful! Such shades
of green & such purple hills one sees
nowhere else; at least I have never
seen it them- My precious wifie must & shall
come down before I return- Last eve-
ning, Dr Kean, & Dr Harvard & Dr Stone
of the Army came aboard to see me
of course I was delighted to see them-
Kean is the best fellow that ever lived
& says that I shan't expose myself in
the least. No case of fever has oc-
curred at Columbia Barracks. Mrs.
Kean is coming down in about 3 weeks &
will live at Camp Columbia- I shall
enjoy their society so much- We will
reach Havana at one o'clock P.M. in good
time to reach Columbia Barracks by 3 P.M.
Dr Carroll is very much stronger, so Dr
Kean says & will meet me with our
private conveyance- I don't think that I
will let him go back to the U.S. on leave.
By remaining, we can complete our work
here & be back by Dec. 15th, and then we
can take up our teaching at Columbian
College & earn a part of our salaries.
I must send off my orders for trees
as soon as I get settled- Dr Roach
wrote me a very nice letter just
before I left Washington & sent me
the address of the party in Albemarle
County who sells albermarle pippins-
I must write to them also- Has dear
little Cocoon begun her school? I hope
so and I fondly expect so- I know that
she and mother are enjoying themselves
now that old Mr Mantee has gone & left
them to their own inclinations- What
a relief to dear Room-fixer it must be
to get that horridly disagreeable man
away! I shall disappoint you, lovie,
dear, by coming back and knocking all
of your “presentments” sky-high! Dear
me! I have written such a long letter
that it will take sweet Cocoon half
a day to decipher it- of course, I shan't
expect that dear Room-fixer will bother
about reading it! I shouldn't advise
her to strain her eyes! The rest of the
page must be left for a word when
we reach Havana- Boo! Boo!! --
1.30 P.M. Here we are in Havana
on a beautiful October afternoon-
Am very well & happy- Love &
Kisses to my precious children-
Write when you feel like it!
Boo! Boo!
